stories.title: The Bone Citadel's Hunger
stories.text:
Varak Ironhelm led eight hundred warriors to breach the Ossuary's gates. The fortress did not defend itself—it devoured.

Walls of living calcium split and swallowed men whole. Towers bent like intestines, peristaltic and hungry. Seven hundred fell screaming into architecture that breathed. The final hundred clawed upward through endless corridors that rearranged themselves around their bodies.

Varak alone reached the throne room. There, he understood: the Ossuary was not conquered. It chose him. Chose to wear his flesh as a glove, to pilot his body while his consciousness screamed trapped inside.

He turned to face his own surviving soldiers, sword raised in borrowed hands. His mouth spoke words his mind did not think. The thing wearing Varak smiled with teeth that were no longer his own.

The final hundred died knowing their general had become the fortress's will made manifest. And the Ossuary, sated, settled into patient stillness once more.

stories.title: The Weight of Stolen Years
stories.text:
The merchant Torvin made his bargain in desperation: five years of life for his daughter's cure. The demon Varek collected with elegant efficiency, draining time itself from Torvin's bones.

But Sorceress Kira had followed Varek into the merchant's house. She watched from shadow as the demon worked, and when he vanished, she found Torvin aged into a husk, his daughter already flushed with returning health.

"He took five years," Torvin wheezed.

"Yes," Kira said. "But he made a mistake. He showed you his method." She began tracing sigils in the dust, her voice sharp as broken glass. "Demons are patient because they believe we cannot match their bargains. But I can steal back what was stolen. It will cost you more than gold."

Torvin nodded. Anything.

Kira's ritual burned through the night. By dawn, Torvin was younger—but hollow-eyed, stripped of all certainty that his daughter truly loved him. The years returned to his body; the doubt remained forever.

As Kira collected her fee—his certainty—Varek watched from elsewhere, impressed by her ingenuity. A partnership began that morning.

stories.title: The Shade-Merchant's Gambit
stories.text:
Vex the Shade-Merchant swaggered into Pelimor's night markets with a fortune in stolen shadows. He'd liberated them from a dying sorcerer's vault—untraceable, priceless, and his to sell for triple his investment.

The anonymous buyers circled. One cloaked woman made her offer: three thousand gold for his entire stock. Vex laughed and countered. They haggled until midnight, until he accepted.

The shadows transferred into clay jars. Vex opened the first to verify quality.

Inside, a shadow moved with malice. He recognized it an instant too late—his own shadow, worn like a second skin by something that remembered his crimes. It had been circulating the markets for months, and she'd bought it back to trap him.

The shadow compelled his body northward, out of Pelimor, eastward into wastes where no one knew his name. Vex screamed soundlessly inside his own flesh as the cloaked woman vanished into the crowd, leaving no trace.

In the markets, merchants whispered: some shadows bite back. Some buyers are not who they seem.

And Vex's remaining stock sold to the highest bidder by morning.

stories.title: The Carver's Final Work
stories.text:
Naresh the Bone Carver had spent twenty years animating the dead. Finger bones danced. Skulls spoke prophecies. But true life—a skeleton that grew, learned, yearned—remained impossible. Until the night of the blue eclipse. Naresh carved by moonlight stained indigo, her chisel moving with fevered precision. She carved lungs that might breathe. A heart-bone that might beat. A mind of ivory that might *want* something beyond compulsion. The ritual consumed her incrementally. Each breath of the skeleton required a breath of her own—not physically, but something deeper. Memories dissolved. Love became abstract concept. Fear evaporated. By the moment the skeleton drew its first true breath and wept, Naresh had become a hollow instrument of pure will. She could not smile at her creation. Could not feel pride or wonder. The skeleton looked at its carver with wet eyes and asked, "What is joy?"

Naresh tried to answer. Her mouth moved. She had spent her humanity teaching it to feel, and in doing so, had forgotten what feelings were. She set down her chisel—a thing that was no longer hers—and walked into the wasteland, a shell containing only purpose.

stories.title: The Blademaster's Last Duel
stories.text:
Kestran had killed forty men in single combat. Forty blood-debts hung on his conscience like stones. He'd sworn an oath to none of them, thinking death was release. He was wrong. The first ghost manifested on a rain-soaked road: one of his earliest kills, a conscripted boy who'd drawn steel only to feed his mother. The boy's shade moved like mist, but his sword-arm held true. Kestran fought himself into exhaustion, but ghosts tire slowly. "Release me," the boy whispered. "Speak the oath you should have sworn when you took my life."

Kestran fell to his knees in mud. "I swear by steel and scar: your death was my fault. Your blood stains me. I release you from your vigil."

The ghost scattered like smoke. Thirty-nine more waited in the weeks that followed. Each demanded the same—honest acknowledgment, genuine contrition, the oath sworn too late. Kestran grew thin, scarred by spectral blades, his mind fractured by accumulated remorse. He spoke the oath with a steady voice, accepting the full measure of his sins. As the last shade faded, it smiled. Kestran sheathed his sword. He would never draw it again.

stories.title: The Lich-King's Collectors
stories.text:
The brigand Soroth found Malachar's gold in a tomb—three hundred pieces stamped with a skeletal crown. Enough to buy a province. He bought horses, hired soldiers, established himself as warlord of the Crimson Vale. For three months, fortune smiled. Then the collectors arrived. They were neither living nor dead—gray things that wore nobility like ill-fitting clothes. Each coin of Malachar's gold carried a debt that compounded daily. Interest in blood. Interest in loyalty. Interest in the very years a man carried in his bones. Soroth offered them gold. They laughed. Gold could not pay a debt to the dead. They took his soldiers first—the ones who'd sworn him fealty. Then his horses. Then they began collecting from Soroth himself: years stripped from his life, leaving him aged and brittle. His black hair became silver. His strength became fragility. "Stop," he pleaded. "I'll return the gold."

The lead collector smiled with empty eyes. "You cannot. Malachar's debts are eternal. But you can choose: die now, or serve us and collect from others. Become our agent in the living world, and we will let you age slowly instead of quickly."

Soroth looked at his withered hands. He accepted his damnation. Where Soroth walks now, fear walks beside him.

stories.title: The Dragon's Bargain
stories.text:
Prince Aldren rode toward the dragon expecting to die heroically. Instead, Skyrakis the Wound-Wing offered him a choice.

"Your kingdom burns because your father broke an ancient oath. I will spare your people—if you take his place."

"What oath?" Aldren asked.

"A blood-marriage, sworn by his grandmother. My daughter is coming of age. Your family promised a prince." The dragon's amber eye was patient, terrible, immense. "You will wed her, rule at her side in the crystal halls beneath the world, and father wyvern-blooded heirs.

In exchange, I will not reduce your kingdom to ash."

Aldren thought of his people. He thought of his bride-to-be, a merchant's daughter waiting in the capital. He thought of the weight of his father's ancient sins.

He dismounted and knelt before the dragon.

"I accept. But I make a counter-oath: that my children will choose whether they serve your mountain or their human kin. Bind no one to unbroken chains."

Skyrakis rumbled with something that might have been laughter. "You negotiate with dragons, boy. I respect that." The vow was sworn in blood and flame.

When Aldren descended into the crystal halls, his bride mourned him as dead. But in the depths, a new world opened—and his choice, freely made, held more honor than the crown ever could.

stories.title: The Thief's Shadow
stories.text:
Mira the Shadow-Dancer had stolen everything except her own shadow. It hung on walls, belonged to no one, and gave her away in daylit streets. A problem for a thief of her caliber.

So she entered Pelimor's night markets and bought a replacement: a merchant's shadow, stolen years ago, anonymous and unremarkable. She wore it like a cloak made of stolen darkness.

For three months, it worked perfectly. She robbed vaults in broad daylight, her false shadow betraying nothing. But shadows retain memory. One night, she felt the merchant's shadow stir with its own will—watching the noble she was robbing, remembering the night it had been cut away.

The shadow wanted revenge.

Mira lost control. Her body moved independent of her mind, fingers betraying her, leading her toward the noble's guard. She fought the shadow's compulsion with every skill she possessed, but shadows are patient and persistent.

At the last moment, she did the unthinkable: she removed the stolen shadow entirely and cast it into flame.

It burned with the merchant's scream. The pain of its incineration threw her to the ground, and she understood: buying a shadow meant inheriting its grief. She retrieved her own shadow from Pelimor's vaults and paid triple.

Now Mira steals only daylight treasures. Shadows, she learned, are never truly for sale.

stories.title: The Oath-Breaker's Curse
stories.text:
Tormund was a king who swore oaths carelessly. He promised his sister lands that weren't his to give. He vowed loyalty to an ally he immediately betrayed. He sealed marriage-bonds he never honored. The curse was elegant: every oath Tormund broke or would break would drain something irreplaceable. First oath broken—he lost his sense of taste. Second—his ability to laugh. Third—his memory of why he loved his firstborn son. By the twentieth broken oath, Tormund was hollow, moving through his throne room like a ghost still bound to flesh. He couldn't taste poison in wine. Couldn't laugh at his ministers' jokes. Couldn't remember his own children's names. Desperate, he sought the cursewright's heir—a young woman living as a hermit in the wastelands. "Release me," Tormund begged. "I'll keep every oath from this moment forward."

She smiled sadly. "The curse was designed to teach you what you've already forgotten: oaths are not chains you wear—they're bonds you forge with others. You can't buy your way out. You can only rebuild by honoring every promise until you remember what it means to be bound."

Tormund spent his final years keeping small oaths to small people. He died without his crown, finally at peace.

stories.title: The City That Remembers
stories.text:
The ruins of Aethermarch were supposed to be dead stone. Instead, the archaeologist Lyssa discovered the city was dreaming.

Each building retained memories of its inhabitants: libraries held ghost-echoes of scholars' debates; temples thrummed with the prayers of forgotten worshippers. Walk through the plaza, and you could feel the footsteps of ten thousand years of merchants and children and lovers.

Lyssa spent weeks mapping the memory-stones, touching walls and hearing their histories. The knowledge was intoxicating—an entire civilization's worth of lost wisdom, accessible for a mere touch.

Then the city began to change her.

Memories bled into her own thoughts. She found herself speaking in ancient tongues. Her fingers moved with crafts she'd never learned. The city was opening her mind to accommodate its vast remembrance, and she was being erased incrementally, replaced by something that was partially Lyssa and partially Aethermarch itself.

She fought her way out of the ruins, burning bridges behind her. The city's call followed—a siren-song of perfect knowledge, perfect understanding, the promise of becoming something eternal and wise.

When she reached the desert's edge, Lyssa was barely herself. Half her thoughts belonged to dead architects. Her dreams spoke in languages that had no living speakers.

She lived, but the cost was terrible. She could never go back.
